item.title: Is Mobility Killing Your Company?
item.description: Initially, only a few executives used company cell phones, which made sense for accessibility. However, this practice expanded to various levels of management, ultimately leading to company-issued smartphones for everyone. While this enhanced communication and response time, it resulted in a complex network of individual contracts and bills due to a phased implementation. Consequently, managing numerous contracts and potentially unused devices became a challenge. Instead of handling this burden, businesses can outsource wireless cost control to specialized companies.

item.title: Tips To Reduce Your Telecom Costs
item.description: By: John Shepler Businesses are facing a challenging time as they grapple with the fluctuating economic landscape brought on by the Covid-19 crisis. While growth was once the primary focus, survival has now taken center stage, making cost control paramount. Let’s explore some immediate steps you can take to reduce expenses without jeopardizing operations. Are You Paying For Unused Services? It might seem improbable, but both individuals and businesses frequently pay for services they don’t utilize.

item.title: POTS Phone Service For Multiple Locations
item.description: Businesses with numerous branches across the US, Canada, and Puerto Rico often struggle with a mountain of paperwork. This isn’t due to government forms but rather a deluge of phone bills from managing services at multiple locations. Initially, a company starts at one location, orders phone and internet services, and handles one or two bills. Someone reviews these bills for errors, unused services, or potential misuse. However, as the company expands to new locations, each branch typically sets up its own phone service, leading to separate bills and individual reviews, multiplying the administrative burden significantly.
